intro: Brassica oleracea convar. botrytis, commonly known as cauliflower, is a cool-season crop characterized by its dense, compact inflorescence. The plant belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is cultivated for its edible flower heads, which are composed of tightly packed modified leaves called florets. It requires a short day length for proper head formation and thrives in well-drained, fertile soil. The plant typically grows to a height of 50–100 cm and has a rosette-like structure with thick, waxy leaves. It is susceptible to certain pests and diseases, including aphids and black rot, requiring careful management in cultivation.
